Further corruption turned the original phonetic {{zh-l|*æ—¡}} into {{lang|zh|â¿±çˆ«å†–}}.

===Etymology===
Based on {{zh-ref|Baxter's (1992)}} {{cog|och|-}} reconstruction {{IPAfont|/*Ê”É¨ts/}}, STEDT suggests that it is from {{inh|zh|sit-pro|*Å‹-(w)aËj||to copulate; to love; to be gentle}}. Compare {{cog|kar-pro|*Ê”ai||to love}}, whence {{cog|blk|tr=Ê”Ã¡i|t=to love}}, {{cog|ksw|á€¡á€²á£á€º||to love}}; {{cog|bfs|eâ´â´||love}}; {{cog|lus|hma-ngaih|hma-'''ngaih'''|to love, to like}}; {{cog|kac|nwai||to respect, to love}}, {{m|kac|ngwi||to be gentle}}; {{cog|my|á€„á€½á€±á€·|t=to be gentle, moderate}}. The Chinese word is related to a Tibeto-Burman allofam without initial ''*Å‹-''. STEDT states that an {{cog|och|-}} reconstruction of {{IPAfont|/*Ê”É¨js/}} for {{lang|zh|æ„›}} is also possible because {{cog|och|-}} rhyming does not provide direct evidence of contacts with ''*-t''.

However, {{zh-ref|Baxter and Sagart (2014)}} reconstructs {{IPAfont|/*[q]ËÉ™[p]-s/}}, which ends in ''*-p-s'' instead. The {{cog|och|-}} contrast between ''*-p-s'' and ''*-t-s'' was lost at a late stage of {{cog|och|-}}. The final ''*-p'' is not reflected in the {{cog|tbq}} comparandum provided by STEDT, making the likelihood that the Chinese form is related to the rest very low ({{zh-ref|Sagart, 2019}}). {{zh-ref|Behr (2016)}} suggests a derivation from a verbal root meaning "to draw in; to inhale; to suck in", relating it to {{och-l|å¸|to inhale|tr=*qÊ°(r)É™p}}, {{och-l|æ¬±|to sip|tr=*qÊ°Ë[É™]p}}, {{och-l|æ„¾|to sigh with regret|tr=*qÊ°É™p-s}}, {{och-l|åƒ¾|to pant|tr=*qËÉ™p-s}}, {{och-l|æ°£|vapour; breath|tr=*C.qÊ°É™p-s}}.

Using the word {{zh-l|å–œæ­¡}} literally means ''like'', but when used in a romantic context (especially boyfriend/girlfriend), it actually means love.
